text: The partial closure of the federal government has exacerbated the differences over how best to secure the southern border. "I think there are serious differences about what we must do for border security," Louis, a democracy, told WNYC Radio host Brian Leherer. Louis, who chairs the House Appropriations Committee, called the amount of opiates coming through ports of entry "a real threat." People must know that opiates reached the United States through smugglers approaching legal entry points. "The facts are, the majority of opiates and all kinds of other substances associated with opiates come from the point of entry," she said. "They don't come with one person, maybe some. But they come in trucks, they come in cars, and they enter directly from the point of entry." She later added: "The fence, the wall and the concrete wall that the President is talking about, from most of the experts, makes no difference." Given the debate over the construction of a wall along the southern border, as well as the lives lost due to opioid addiction, we wondered if Louie was right. Does most opiates come through legal ports of entry and not across borders where President Trump wants to build a wall? Background information on Trump, in support of his case for the wall, sometimes said that it would stop the flow of drugs. In budget note 2019, the Administration stated, "The construction of the wall is crucial to hinder and prevent the flow of illicit drugs into our country." The south-west border "remains the main entry point for heroin into the United States," according to the Drug Enforcement Agency. The United States has more than 300 ports of entry, with United States customs and border protection officers inspecting passengers and cargo. Enforcement in these ports of entry, such as airports and shipping facilities, is the responsibility of the Customs and Border Protection Field Operations Office. Enforcement between ports of entry is the responsibility of the Customs and Border Protection Authority Border Patrol. While we cannot measure heroin that comes into the country without detection, it should be noted that federal data since at least 2012 have been consistent in showing that agents encounter heroin at ports of entry much more than between ports of entry. Mike Burns, Louie's spokesman, referred to applied customs and border protection statistics in the United States to support her claim. The data show that the number of drugs detected at ports of entry far exceeds the number of drugs detected between ports of entry. The Field Operations Office, which operates at ports of entry, seized 4,813 pounds of heroin during the first 11 months of fiscal year 2018, until 31 August 2018. During the same period, the United States Border Patrol, which operates between legal ports of entry, seized 532 pounds of heroin. Statistics from the Customs and Border Protection Office from 2012 to 2017 show similar discrepancies between heroin seized at ports of entry and heroin seized between ports of entry. The data also show that Fentanyl, another opium, was seized at ports of entry at a higher rate than at points of entry between ports of entry.
